article_title: Ben Carson, the ‘anti-Trump,’ brings conservative message to S.F.
article_text:
Ben Carson, the ‘anti-Trump,’ brings conservative message to S.F.

Photo: Connor Radnovich, The Chronicle Republican presidential candidate Dr. Ben Carson laughs while...

Ben Carson, the only Republican presidential candidate within striking distance of Donald Trump, burnished his conservative credentials in San Francisco on Tuesday when he rejected Gov. Jerry Brown’s dismissal of Republicans who refuse to accept evidence of human-caused climate change as “troglodytes.”

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Carla Marinucci
article_metadata.description: Ben Carson, the only Republican presidential candidate within striking distance of Donald Trump, burnished his conservative credentials in San Francisco on Tuesday when he rejected Gov. Jerry Brown’s dismissal of Republicans who refuse to accept evidence of human-caused climate change as “troglodytes.”  “I know there are a lot of people who say ‘overwhelming science,’ but then when you ask them to show the overwhelming science, they never can show it,” Carson said in an interview with The Chronicle after his sold-out appearance at the Commonwealth Club.  The retired neurosurgeon and political neophyte, who has been called the “anti-Trump,” spoke at the Mark Hopkins Hotel before hundreds of followers and some curious Democrats, including former Mayor Willie Brown, a Chronicle columnist.  While he delivered few policy details, Carson’s soft-spoken delivery and upbeat, motivational approach resonated with many in the crowd while providing a stylistic contrast to the brash Republican front-runner.  On issues, Carson criticized Obamacare as unworkable, called for a flat tax system and said the country’s most looming problems were the deficit and the rise of “global jihadism,” which he said must be wiped out at all costs.  On reproductive rights, he called Planned Parenthood founder Margaret Sanger “a despicable person” and outlined his unshakable antiabortion stance, saying that having spent my entire professional career trying to save lives ...  Asked if he believed gay marriage has been settled by the courts, Carson said, “I don’t think it is any more settled than abortion,” a brave statement to make in the birthplace of same-sex marriage.  Our Constitution says that civil issues, like the gay marriage issue, should be handled at the state level.  [...] the reason (the founding fathers) said that is because the legislators and the judges at the state level are subject to the will of the people.  Carson’s appearance in San Francisco came as a judge released Rowan County (Ky.) Clerk Kim Davis from prison, where she had been sent for contempt of court after refusing to sign licenses for same-sex marriages, citing her Christian faith.
